title: Study on the Dynamic Response and Collapse Failure of 500kv DC Transmission Tower Line System Under Multi-Point Earthquake Excitation
authors: Hongbin Zai, Haoyu Liu, Yujun Li
publish: 2025 2nd international conference on DC technologies and systems (DCTS)
abstract: In recent years, while the overall seismic activity in China has remained relatively stable, the characteristics of high frequency, high intensity, and wide distribution persist, posing a significant threat to the safety of power transmission corridors. Earthquakes are typically considered as a singlepoint excitation source. To investigate the effects of both singlepoint and multi-point excitations on a transmission tower-line system, this paper develops a finite element (FE) model of a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 0 0 k V}$</tex> “three-tower, two-line” Direct Current (DC) transmission system based on an actual engineering project. The model was established by comprehensively considering material and geometric nonlinearities and through the appropriate selection of element types. Subsequently, artificial multi-point seismic waves, conforming to realistic conditions, were generated based on the number of excitation points and their distances from the transmission towers. The results indicate that, under both excitation scenarios, the structural responses induced by multi-point excitation are greater than those induced by single-point excitation. In terms of member stress response, the calculated stresses in the primary members of the towers exhibit a decreasing trend with increasing tower height, regardless of whether the seismic input is one-dimensional or two-dimensional. Furthermore, due to the more pronounced restraining effect of the transmission lines on the end towers, these towers are subjected to greater lateral forces during an earthquake. The findings of this study provide a practical reference for the stability analysis and reinforcement of DC transmission towers under seismic conditions.

title: The Hook-in-CBEWS Framework: A Behavioral Design Framework for Enhancing Engagement in Community-Based Early Warning Systems
authors: Dimas Budianto, Lukito Edi Nugroho, Azkario Rizky Pratama
publish: 2025 International Conference on Applied Artificial Intelligence, Data Engineering and Sciences (ICAIDES)
abstract: Community disengagement remains a persistent challenge in sustaining the effectiveness of Community-Based Early Warning Systems (CBEWS) in Indonesia’s coastal areas. Addressing this “last-mile gap” requires frameworks that move beyond information dissemination toward behaviorally sustained participation. This paper introduces the Hook-in-CBEWS Framework, a proposed behavioral design framework that integrates the Hook Model phases (Trigger, Action, Reward, and Investment) into the four core elements of CBEWS. Developed through the Design Science Research Methodology (DSRM) combined with the Best-Fit Framework Synthesis (BFFS), this study conducted a preliminary verification focusing on conceptual feasibility and stakeholder acceptability (DSRM Activity 4), establishing a necessary foundation prior to behavioral validation. Empirical and theoretical triangulation was conducted using mixed methods involving small-scale fishermen in Parangtritis, Yogyakarta. Nineteen design patterns classified as critical were identified, providing structured behavioral mechanisms that align with user needs and contextual characteristics observed in the field. The framework offers a prescriptive conceptual foundation for sustainable engagement design and provides empirically grounded design patterns that can guide prototype development. Future work will extend this foundation through prototype deployment and longitudinal behavioral evaluation.

title: A Modular Network Intrusion Detection Architecture Leveraging LLM Fine-Tuning with QLoRA and Textual Representation for Anomaly Detection
authors: Changlong Huang, Zhenzhou An
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Computer Science, Electronic Information Engineering and Intelligent Control Technology (CEI)
abstract: The study introduces an intrusion detection architecture based on the modularity of the network that includes Large Language Models (LLMs), to support accurate determination of complex network anomalies, especially focusing on Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attack techniques. The underlying model uses Llama3, which has been optimized with PEFT (Parameter-Efficient Fine-Tuning). When combined with QLoRA (Quantized Low-Rank Adaptation), it minimizes computational resource consumption. A new algorithm transforms structured network flow data to a natural language format. This makes it acceptable for LLMs to absorb instructions. It creates operational efficiency within the framework due to its simplicity and ability simplify later labor steps of word count and conversion back into codes. Also added is a feature selection stage, using the Pearson coefficient, to effectively manage data dimension. When the approach is evaluated in four different datasets (CIC-IDS2017, CIC-DDoS2019, CIC-IoT2023 and InSDN), it shows robust performance: the non-DDoS categories are consistently very accurate (ACC <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\geq 0.999$</tex>) with extremely low False Positive Rates (FPR <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\leq \mathbf{0. 0 0 0 9}$</tex>). This was at variance from the test given in the CIC-DDoS2019 data, where for the DDoS model both ACC and FPR were observed fall dramatically, from 0.9879 to 0.9770 and from 0.0106 to 0.0183 respectively, across various classifiable models. These findings have two aspects. The system must accurately discriminate standard network traffic from complex DDoS attack signatures and clearly articulate the unique properties of those threats. This in consequence calls for an urgent investigation of feature optimization and tactical adjustment of thresholds, both required to reinforce network resilience against such sophisticated cyber-attack forms.

title: Mechanism and Solutions of False Trip Caused by Main Signal Latching Fault in Valve Control System of UHVDC Flexible Converter Station
authors: Yukun Xiao, Wanli Shi, Sai Ding, Chang Ruan, Hangtian Dong, Peng Zhang, Xiaoxia Li, Jianhua Lu
publish: 2025 2nd international conference on DC technologies and systems (DCTS)
abstract: Aiming at the false trip problem caused by the main signal latching fault in the Valve Control Protection (VCP) system of a UHVDC flexible converter station (hereinafter referred to as “flexible converter station”), this paper first sorts out the typical dual-set hot standby redundancy architecture of the UHVDC flexible DC valve control system and the transmission paths of main signals (ACTIVE, VBC_OK). Secondly, the impact of the main signal latching fault on the operation of the valve control system is verified through simulation, and the root cause of the fault is located by combining the duty logic of the main/standby sets. Finally, two types of rectification measures are proposed: “adding reset logic” and “independent power supply configuration”. The proposed scheme can effectively solve the main signal latching problem, improve the operation reliability of the valve control system, and provide technical reference for the design of the valve control system in subsequent UHVDC flexible DC projects.

title: Complex Scene Object Recognition and Segmentation Model Integrating Self-supervised Learning and Numerical Optimization Algorithm
authors: Haoting Xia
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Computer Science, Electronic Information Engineering and Intelligent Control Technology (CEI)
abstract: In the segmentation of complex scenes, training data are limited and boundaries are irregular. To alleviate these problems, in this paper, we propose a new method which combines self-supervised learning and numerical optimization. Firstly, through pixel-by-pixel self-supervised pre-training, more discriminative features learned are insensitive to occlusion and scale, thereby reducing the need of labeled data. Secondly, an energy function describing the boundary is constructed based on active contour model, which converts the optimization problem of boundary to a numerical optimization problem. Finally, quasi-Newton method is employed to effectively minimize the energy and obtain refined boundaries. The experiments on the dataset show that compared with the baseline model, our model can get the MIoU of 73.6 % and boundary F-measure of 78.9 %. Especially, the boundary quality is improved a lot in occluded scenes, which verifies the effectiveness and advantages of our method improving segmentation accuracy and boundary quality.

title: A Continuous-Wave Wind Lidar System based on an Adaptive Threshold Peak Retrieval Algorithm
authors: Haixin Qu, Haifeng Qi, Shujuan Li, Pengbo Jiang, Jian Guo, Li Min, Jiasheng Ni, Zhiqiang Song, Shujie Tan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Signal Processing and Communication Technology (SPCT)
abstract: Continuous-wave wind lidar (CWL) is a core device in fields such as meteorological observation and wind power operation and maintenance. The accuracy of wind speed retrieval directly depends on the peak finding accuracy of signal processing of CWL. Firstly, according to the construction of a 1.5μm CWL system, the kernel density estimation model is determined as the noise fitting model with the best noise, and the noise baseline is determined. Then, an adaptive threshold peak retrieval algorithm based on morphological filtering and gradient detection is proposed. The algorithm achieves accurate peak search through multi-feature fusion and threshold screening. The final experiment shows that the algorithm can stably and accurately identify one peak in each measurement, and the highest confidence is 0.906, which effectively solves the problem of multi-peak misjudgment and insufficient confidence inherent in the traditional method. The algorithm improves the accuracy of Doppler frequency shift extraction, thereby supporting precise wind speed measurement with CWL.

title: A Comparative Failure Analysis of Object Detection in Orthopantomography
authors: Hizkia Imanuel Septianto, Tatiya Sucitta, David Zefanya Malau, Abram Setyo Prabowo, S. Kom
publish: 2025 International Conference on Applied Artificial Intelligence, Data Engineering and Sciences (ICAIDES)
abstract: In the dental imaging domain, automatic detection of dental anomalies from OPG images remains one of the crucial challenges. This study systematically compares the impact of an extended dataset for self-supervised pre-training using Masked Autoencoders (MAE) on two well-known architectures in the dental imaging domain—ConvNeXt and Swin Transformer. However, our results show that all four model configurations fail to achieve clinically adequate performance, with the bestperforming model (Swin-Unextended) only obtaining 0.3002 $\mathbf{m A P} \text{@} \mathbf{0 . 5 0}$. This evaluation reveals a crucial contradiction: extended pre-training substantially improves ConvNeXt ($+13.4 \%$ mAP) but unexpectedly decreases the performance of Swin Transformer ($-2.3 \% \mathrm{mAP}$), indicating severe overfitting. Our quantitative resolution analysis shows that our most difficult-to-detect feature, Periapical Lesions (AP 0.03), still maintains a significant and detectable average size ($\sim 14 \times 50$ pixels) after resizing. This indicates a fundamental failure, rather than a superficial one. We conclude that this failure likely stems from the combined effects of extreme labeled data scarcity and highlights the limitations of MAE for downstream object detection tasks.

title: Method for Identifying Nonlinear Dynamic Control Objects of Beneficiation Technology
authors: Ihor Novitskyi, Mykola Tryputen, Vitalii Kuznetsov
publish: 2024 IEEE 6th International Conference on Modern Electrical and Energy System (MEES)
abstract: The purpose of this work is to develop and test under industrial conditions a method for identifying nonlinear dynamic control objects of beneficiation technology operating in the presence of disturbances. In order to achieve this purpose, analytical methods were used in combination with simulation modeling methods for adjusting the parameters of the mathematical model of the control object. The study focuses on drum mills in the ore preparation technological line before beneficiation. . From the perspective of control, drum mills are nonlinear, nonstationary objects with significant inertia. These factors significantly complicate the task of determining an adequate mathematical model of the object for control. To solve this problem, an identification method was proposed that combines the positive properties of parametric and nonparametric methods, based on the use of a non-traditional criterion for the quality of model adjustment – the sample correlation ratio. The identification method ensures a high speed of selection of operational information about an object; is universal in terms of the object structure; takes into account the presence of nonlinear elements in the composition of the object, and is minimally sensitive to the effects of disturbances. The result of the identification is the determination of the parameters of linear operators and the assessment of the type of characteristic of the nonlinear element as part of the object model.

title: Structural Extraction and Image Measurement Method for Complex Concrete Cracks
authors: Yang Yu, He Tianle, Chen Jie, Xu Xiaohua, Du Zhida, Zhang Chaoyuan
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Image, Signal Processing and Communication Technology (ISPCT)
abstract: To address the challenge of accurately characterizing complex crack morphologies in concrete through holistic measurements, this study proposes an image-based method for structural extraction and measurement of complex cracks. First, a U-Net segmentation model is employed to extract crack mask images, effectively preserving the true morphology of cracks. Subsequently, a recursive skeleton correction algorithm is constructed to obtain single-pixel-wide skeletons, and a two-level structural separation strategy is applied to decompose complex cracks into multiple branches. Finally, the length and width of each branch are calculated, and three width measurement methods are compared. Experimental results demonstrate that the relative error for branch length measurements ranges from 2% to 7%. Among the three width measurement methods, the orthogonal skeleton method performs best, with an average relative error of 6.27%, fully validating the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

title: ReviewGraph: A Knowledge Graph Embedding Based Framework for Review Rating Prediction with Sentiment Features
authors: A.J.W. De Vink, Natalia Amat-Lefort, Lifeng Han
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Knowledge Graph (ICKG)
abstract: In the hospitality industry, understanding the factors that drive customer review ratings is critical for improving guest satisfaction and business performance. This work proposes ReviewGraph for Review Rating Prediction (RRP), a novel framework that transforms textual customer reviews into knowledge graphs by extracting subject-predicate-object triples and associating sentiment scores. Using graph embeddings (Node2Vec) and sentiment features, the framework predicts review rating scores through machine learning classifiers. We compare ReviewGraph performance with traditional NLP baselines (such as Bag of Words, TF-IDF, and Word2Vec) and large language models (llMs), evaluating them in the HotelRec dataset. In comparison to the state of the art literature, our proposed model performs similar to their best performing model but with lower computational cost (without ensemble). While ReviewGraph achieves comparable predictive performance to LLMs and outperforms baselines on agreement-based metrics such as Cohen's Kappa, it offers additional advantages in interpretability, visual exploration, and potential integration into Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) systems. This work highlights the potential of graph-based representations for enhancing review analytics and lays the groundwork for future research integrating advanced graph neural networks and fine-tuned LLM-based extraction methods. We will share ReviewGraph output and platform open-sourced at https://github.com/aaronlifenghan/ReviewGraph

title: An ADC-Based Interoperability Evaluation Framework for Unmanned Systems with Combined Weighting Method
authors: Jirong Ren, Weiqi Zhao, Wei Guo, Zhaoxuan Guo, Borui Li, Hao Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Signal Processing and Communication Technology (SPCT)
abstract: Interoperability is a critical factor determining the operational effectiveness of unmanned systems in multi-domain and cross-domain environments. This paper proposes an improved ADC (Availability, Dependability, Capability) evaluation framework integrated with a combined weighting method to assess the interoperability level of unmanned systems. The ADC model, originally developed by the Weapon System Effectiveness Industry Advisory Committee (WSEIAC) in 1965, is adapted to reflect the unique characteristics of unmanned systems, including protocol compatibility, data exchange efficiency, survivability in contested environments, and functional resilience in degraded modes. To address the complexity of weighting determination in interoperability metrics, a combined weighting approach is introduced, balancing subjective weights derived from the Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) and objective weights based on entropy method. The subjective weights incorporate expert judgment on tactical priorities, while the objective weights are calculated from multi-user evaluation data. The two are fused using a relative entropy minimization model to form a balanced combined weight. A case study on "node connectivity", a subdimension of interoperability, demonstrates the applicability of the proposed method. The results show that the combined weighting effectively integrates expert experience and empirical data, providing a comprehensive and practical evaluation tool for unmanned system interoperability.

title: A Physics-Informed Deep Reinforcement Learning Framework for Obstacle Avoidance and Path Planning of AUV
authors: Jiaxing Zhou, Xingfeng Yin, Jinlin Li, Haoyu Gong
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Human-Computer Interaction and Robotics (AIHCIR)
abstract: To address the problem of real-time obstacle avoidance and trajectory planning for autonomous underwater vehicle (AUV) operating in complex and uncertain underwater environments, this paper proposes a physics-informed deep reinforcement learning method (PIDRL). First, a dynamic model of the AUV is established based on the physical characteristics of the underwater environment. Then, a feasibility-checking function is incorporated into the action selection stage, while physics-based constraint terms—related to motion smoothness, attitude stability, and environmental adaptability—are embedded into the reward and loss functions. In this way, environmental physics and dynamic constraints are integrated into the learning framework of the Deep Q-Network. Finally, through simulation training and validation, a policy model is obtained and tested for its obstacle-avoidance and path-planning performance in a designed underwater environment. Simulation results show that, compared with traditional DRL and NMPC algorithms, the proposed method achieves superior performance in obstacle avoidance success rate and path smoothness, with path smoothness improved by 0.06–0.12 and trajectory length reduced by approximately 3%. The results demonstrate that the proposed method exhibits stronger adaptability and robustness, significantly enhancing the AUV’s autonomous obstacle-avoidance and trajectory-planning capabilities in complex dynamic environments, and providing an effective solution for physically reliable underwater intelligent control.

title: DMF-MH:Dual-Stage Modality-Aware Fusion for Modality Heterogeneity in Multimodal Knowledge Graph Completion
authors: Ronghua Tian, Hong Yu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Knowledge Graph (ICKG)
abstract: Multimodal Knowledge Graph Completion (MMKGC) aims to infer missing knowledge in multimodal knowledge graphs (MMKGs) enriched with multimodal entity representations such as textual descriptions and images. However, the intrinsic heterogeneity across modalities poses a significant challenge, often resulting in semantic inconsistency, representation misalignment, and modality conflict. To address these issues, we propose DMF-MH, a Dual-stage Modality-aware Fusion framework specifically designed to mitigate modality heterogeneity in MMKGC. In the first stage, we employ modality-specific encoders to extract independent semantic features, and utilize a bilinear fusion mechanism combined with contrastive learning to explicitly model cross-modal interactions while enforcing alignment between modalities of the same entity. In the second stage, we implement a decision-level fusion strategy that integrates the predictions of each modality using learned reliability-aware weights, enabling robust and adaptive inference. Extensive experiments on three public datasets demonstrate that DMF-MH significantly improves link prediction performance and exhibits strong generalization ability under heterogeneous modality settings.

title: Integrated Study on Material Compatibility and Structural Design for Natural Ester Transformers
authors: Zhijun Zhao, Jian Li, Zongbo Yu, Wei Wang, Xiaoyong Chen, Yongjiao He, Haoxi Cong, Xuefeng Hu
publish: 2025 2nd international conference on DC technologies and systems (DCTS)
abstract: Natural ester insulating oils are increasingly adopted in power transformers due to their high biodegradability and fire safety. However, the long-term reliability of ester-filled transformers is critically dependent on the compatibility between ester oils and solid insulation materials. In this paper, a 120 °C oil-immersion accelerated aging model, equivalent to five years of service according to IEC 62770, is established to systematically investigate the physical, chemical, and electrical compatibility of five representative insulation materials. A multi-scale evaluation framework combining dimensional stability, dissolution behavior, and dielectric performance is proposed. The results reveal that cellulose-based and crosslinked epoxy materials exhibit intrinsic compatibility with natural ester oil, while polyester film suffers severe degradation and significantly deteriorates oil dielectric properties. Based on these findings, material selection criteria are formulated and applied to the design and manufacturing of two 400 kVA natural ester transformer prototypes. Factory test results confirm the engineering feasibility of the proposed compatibility-driven design strategy.

title: Multi-Energy Load Forecasting for Integrated Energy Systems Based on Mamba-Graph Convolutional Networks
authors: Yu Jiang, Xuncheng Zhang, Yongqi Yan, Yudie Sun, Xinyang Wang, Yuyang Ji
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power Conversion and Control Engineering (PCCE)
abstract: Accurately forecasting multi-energy loads is crucial for optimally dispatching and economically operating integrated energy systems (IES). However, most methods commonly ignore the correlation in multi-energy and the global information in long-term series. To solve these issues, we propose a hybrid model based on the Mamba and Graph Convolutional Networks (Mamba-GCN). Specifically, we use GCN to capture the correlation between different energies. In contrast to the implicit learning rules of Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), which learn local patterns within a grid structure, GCN uses a known graph structure that describes the relationships between features or entities to handle correlations. To obtain global information in long-time series, Mamba network is introduced to model cross-time period correlations on a global scale. The effectiveness of the proposed Mamba-GCN is verified using multi-energy load data from Arizona State University.

title: Prevention Label Enrichment in a Network Intrusion Detection System Benchmark Dataset
authors: Muhammad Iqbal, Dony Ariyus, Mohammad Koprawi, Anggit Ferdita Nugraha
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Information System and Information Technology (ICISIT)
abstract: Cyberattacks on networks remain a critical threat, emphasizing the need for proactive defense mechanisms. Although machine learning–based Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) have progressed in detecting threats, their effectiveness is limited to the detection stage and rarely extends to preventive recommendations. This limitation stems from the absence of preventive labels in publicly available datasets, leading to reactive models. To address this gap, this study enriches the benchmark IDS dataset, NSL-KDD, with preventive labels. The methodology includes attack pattern analysis, formulation of mitigation labels, cross-validation with the MITRE CAPEC framework, and expert evaluation. Results show that more than 82.5% of the proposed labels align with appropriate preventive actions, while the remaining were considered inconsistent with actual mitigation strategies. These findings highlight the need to balance tactical responses and a strengthened security posture. The main contribution of this study is a ready-to-use enriched dataset that facilitates the development of next-generation AI models capable of not only detecting but also recommending preventive measures, thereby supporting faster incident response and enhancing cybersecurity resilience.

title: Adaptive Multi-Scale Attention Mechanism for Robust Action Recognition in Complex Scenes
authors: Chen Chen, Di Zhang, Xiangmei Zhao, Na Li
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Computer Science, Electronic Information Engineering and Intelligent Control Technology (CEI)
abstract: Behavior recognition has become a fundamental task in computer vision with broad applications in intelligent surveillance, human-computer interaction, and smart security systems. However, complex real-world scenarios present significant challenges, including occlusion, illumination variation, viewpoint changes, and background clutter, which severely degrade recognition performance. Existing methods primarily rely on fixed-scale feature extraction and single-dimensional attention mechanisms, limiting their robustness in complex environments. To address these issues, this paper proposes an Adaptive Multi-Scale Attention Mechanism (AMSAM) for robust behavior recognition. The proposed method employs a multi-branch convolutional architecture to capture spatiotemporal features at small, medium, and large scales simultaneously. An adaptive attention module integrating spatial, temporal, and channel dimensions is designed to dynamically evaluate feature importance across different scales. Furthermore, a feature alignment and adaptive weighted fusion strategy is developed to enable deep integration of multi-scale information. Extensive experiments on the benchmark datasets UCF101 and HMDB51 demonstrate that AMSAM achieves recognition accuracies of 95.1% and 77.9%. Under challenging scenarios such as occlusion and illumination variation, the proposed method exhibits significantly improved robustness. The results validate the effectiveness and practical applicability of AMSAM for behavior recognition in complex scenarios.

title: Knowledge-Driven Multi-Agent AI for Interpretable Yield Optimization in Semiconductor Manufacturing
authors: Chaojun Geng, Degang Wang, Yanan Liu, Xiupeng Shi
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Human-Computer Interaction and Robotics (AIHCIR)
abstract: Optimizing yield in semiconductor manufacturing is economically critical but challenging because process data are kept highly confidential and anonymized. Traditional machine-learning methods rely on statistical correlations and cannot incorporate physical process knowledge, limiting model interpretability and transferability. We propose a multi-agent AutoML framework that uses large language and vision models to extract physics-based formulas from the literature and inject them into anonymized process data for feature construction. Five autonomous agents retrieve relevant papers, parse formulas, cluster the data, align abstract formula variables with data features, and construct interpretable formula-driven features. On the SECOM dataset, this knowledge-driven approach expands the feature set by 37.6% and improves AUC from 79.85% to 90.59%, with 81.8% of the top predictive features derived from literature formulas. A copula-based recommender then simulates process adjustments by shifting low-yield samples toward high-yield feature regions, raising the mean predicted yield probability from 0.15 to 0.76. Our framework demonstrates how cross-modal knowledge integration and multi-agent optimization can deliver transparent, transferable yield-improvement strategies under strict data confidentiality.

title: Machine Learning-Based Prediction for Dynamic Line Rating of Transmission Lines
authors: Haoyu Wang, Changcheng Song, Xiaodong Chu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power System and Renewable Energy (PSRE)
abstract: Under the global energy transition and the advancement of the “dual carbon” goals, the intermittency and volatility of renewable energy renders traditional static power transmission inadequate. Day-ahead prediction of dynamic transmission capacity is crucial for grid stability. Based on the principles of dynamic line rating and the thermal balance equation, this study improves traditional recurrent neural networks by incorporating an attention mechanism. Utilizing historical weather data, a day-ahead prediction model for dynamic transmission capacity is developed. Through 100 days of historical data for training and validation, the proposed method can accurately output the maximum allowable hourly ampacity and transmission capacity for the following day, with prediction accuracy surpassing that of traditional models. The approach provides a scientific basis for grid dispatch, supporting renewable energy integration and grid security.

title: Implementation of the Online Virtual Labs in Electrical Engineering in the Learning Environment of Higher Education Institution
authors: Dmytro Babenko, Nataliia Dotsenko, Olena Gorbenko
publish: 2024 IEEE 6th International Conference on Modern Electrical and Energy System (MEES)
abstract: In the article is presented the implementation of the online virtual labs in electrical engineering in the learning environment of higher education institution. There are outlined the necessity in using online virtual labs for training future electrical engineers in modern conditions. The proposed technology consists of the preliminary, pilot, implementation and improvement stages. Also, there are developed the criteria of evaluation of the online virtual labs in electrical engineering in the educational environment of higher education institution. On the each of the stages the online virtual labs that are going to use for training of the specialists in electrical engineering is necessary to be checked on the basis of the proposed criteria. After the implementation of the online virtual labs there were checked the level of knowledge of students. There were used the Pearson criterion to investigate the effectiveness of the proposed pedagogical technology statistically.

title: Comparative Analysis of CNN Architectures’ Performance with Vision Transformer for Batik Type Classification
authors: Albert Yakobus Chandra, Putry Wahyu Setyaningsih, Irfan Pratama
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Information System and Information Technology (ICISIT)
abstract: This study investigates the performance of four deep learning architectures—Vision Transformer (ViT), VGG-16, ResNet-50, and a Generic CNN—on the task of batik pattern classification involving 20 distinct classes. The dataset presents significant challenges due to its fine-grained structural complexity, necessitating models with advanced feature extraction capabilities and robust class-discriminative power. Despite the extensive use of CNNs in image classification, their limitations in capturing global spatial relationships motivated this study to explore the Vision Transformer (ViT) as a potential alternative. ViT demonstrates state-of-the-art performance, achieving an accuracy of 0.8688 alongside closely aligned macro precision, recall, and F1-score values (0.8832, 0.8688, and 0.8694, respectively). These results highlight ViT’s ability to maintain balanced predictive performance across all classes, supported by its self-attention mechanisms that effectively represent intricate spatial relationships. This research contributes to the field by systematically comparing ViT and CNN-based architectures for batik classification, addressing the research gap in applying advanced machine learning techniques to preserve cultural heritage. Future work will focus on confidence calibration, robustness assessments, and detailed per-class error analysis to ensure the model’s reliability and applicability in real-world scenarios.

title: The Optimal Regenerative Braking Control of BLDC Motor for Light Electric Vehicle
authors: Ihor Shchur, Mariusz Korkosz, Volodymyr Koziy
publish: 2024 IEEE 6th International Conference on Modern Electrical and Energy System (MEES)
abstract: Drives of light electric vehicles (LEV) are implemented, as a rule, based on brushless direct current (BLDC) motors, which are characterized by high specific energy indicators, reliability and ease of control. To extend the range of LEVs, it is advisable to apply BLDC motor regenerative braking. In this work, using the example of an electric bicycle drive system, it is shown how to determine the optimal conditions of BLDC motor electric braking from the point of view of the maximum recuperation power. The proposed LEV brake system is hybrid with an electric and friction brake subsystems that automatically complement each other, and the electric braking, if possible, is carried out according to the determined optimal trajectories. As the computer simulation showed, the proposed braking system makes it possible to increase the amount of energy recovered in the battery during braking of the electric bicycle by up to 30% compared to the traditional regenerative braking system.

title: Approximation Algorithm for Minimum Weight Sweep Coverage Without Predetermined Sinks
authors: Weiguang Zhang, Jiarong Liang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Computer Science, Electronic Information Engineering and Intelligent Control Technology (CEI)
abstract: Coverage of points of interest (PoIs) is essential for wireless sensor networks (WSNs) to achieve situation awareness and data collection. In some application scenarios, PoIs are unnecessary to be cover all the time. Therefore, it is more efficient and economical to schedule mobile sensors to cover PoIs periodically than use extensive static sensors to cover PoIs continuously, which motivates the research on sweep coverage. Mobile sensors should visit sinks (base stations) periodically within a given time or distance constraint so that they could be refueled or upload the collected data. To obtain a better sweep coverage scheme, most existing works only consider the cost of mobile sensors and study the sweep coverage problem with minimum mobile sensors. However, the deployment of sinks and their cost should also be considered. In this paper, we consider the minimum weight sweep coverage problem. We propose an approximation algorithm called A4MWSCS for this problem, whose approximation ratio is 3. We conduct simulation experiments to evaluate the performance of A4MWSCS and compare it with the related state-of-the-art algorithms. The simulation results show that our algorithm can obtain a smaller cost sweep coverage scheme for the problem.

title: A Dual-Strategy Framework for High-Resolution Typographic Defect Segmentation
authors: Wenzheng Huang, Zhanchong Liu, Yasunori Sakai, Jiachen Yuan
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Human-Computer Interaction and Robotics (AIHCIR)
abstract: High-resolution typographic quality control is challenged by the detection of micro-defects, which are often minuscule and sparsely distributed, leading to a severe class imbalance problem. This paper proposes a novel end-to-end framework to address this issue. We introduce a dual-strategy for training, which combines data-level weighted patch sampling with a loss-level composite function comprising Weighted Cross-Entropy, Dice, and Focal losses. The segmentation network leverages a convolutional neural network (CNN) backbone with a semantic segmentation architecture to achieve robust feature extraction and precise localization. For practical deployment, we design a seamless inference pipeline using an overlapping sliding window to process ultra-high-resolution images without artifacts. Furthermore, an application-specific post-processing step generates intuitive visualizations for industrial quality inspection. Our experiments demonstrate that this comprehensive approach significantly improves the detection accuracy of typographic defects, providing a robust and practical solution for automated quality assurance.

title: Patient Similarity Prediction Based on Facial Diagnosis Features
authors: Xi Guo, Xiaodi Li, Wulamu Aziguli, Wenhui Na
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Human-Computer Interaction and Robotics (AIHCIR)
abstract: This study addresses the subjectivity in Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) facial diagnosis and the lack of objective patient similarity metrics by developing a deep learning model for quantitative facial feature extraction and similarity prediction. Using computer vision, facial Regions of Interest (ROIs) are automatically located, and features such as facial color, lip color, and face shape are extracted into structured vectors. A siamese network with a transformer encoder maps features into a shared latent space for end-to-end similarity computation. Experiments demonstrate strong performance, with a Pearson correlation coefficient of 0.9357, confirming the model's effectiveness in supporting TCM clinical decisions and advancing intelligent TCM research.

title: A Direct-Capacitance-Conversion FeRAM Characterization Platform for Enabling Non-Destructive 3D Ferroelectric Capacitor Readout
authors: Xiongfei Jiang, Chaohan Wang, Yang Xiang, Shiwei Wang, Themis Prodromakis, Marie Garcia Bardon, Jan Van Houdt, Fernando Garcia Redondo, Dwaipayan Biswas
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems II: Express Briefs
abstract: Ferroelectric-capacitor-based memory (FeRAM) is a promising emerging non-volatile memory technology that offers fast access and high endurance. Recent studies have demonstrated Ferroelectric-capacitor-based memory (FeRAM) has the potential to support Non-Destructive Readout (NDRO) as well as 3D stacking, enabling read operations that do not disturb or minor disturb the stored polarization state and higher density. However, variations in ferroelectric materials and layer structures lead to diverse hysteresis behaviors, resulting in different sensing requirements. In addition, the reduced capacitor size in deeply stacked 3D architectures further decreases the available charge, making accurate readout increasingly challenging. To better understand these issues, this work presents a highly scalable direct-capacitance-conversion characterization circuit that is capable of extracting the equivalent ferroelectric capacitance from a 3D FeRAM array. Leveraging a continuous-time delta-sigma modulator (CTDSM), the proposed platform can accurately quantize small ferroelectric equivalent capacitances ranging from 0 to 72fF with low noise and high resolution, and achieves a capacitance resolution of 0.045fF<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">rms</sub> while consuming only 3μW power and occupying 0.001mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> chip area under a 22nm FDSOI technology. These results demonstrate the capability to characterize 3D FeRAM arrays with up to 64 vertically stacked ferroelectric capacitors (FeCAPs) and highlight strong scalability for large-scale FeRAM evaluation and design exploration.

title: Enhanced Field-Oriented Control for Induction Motors Under Open-Circuit Faults Using Decoupled Speed and Flux Control with Adaptive Control Technique
authors: Mohammad Alathamneh, Haneen Ghanayem, Ibrahim M. Allafi, Ashraf Bani Ahmad, R. M. Nelms
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Industrial Electronics Society
abstract: This paper presents an enhanced fault-tolerant control framework for induction motor drive systems, emphasizing resilience, adaptability, and system-level reliability in interconnected industrial environments. A modified field-oriented control structure is developed to ensure decoupled flux and speed regulation under open-circuit fault conditions. The proposed control integrates an adaptive proportional–integral–resonant (PIR) controller within a reconfigured stationary reference frame to maintain stable operation even during partial phase loss. By continuously adjusting its resonant frequency in response to real-time feedback, the controller achieves superior transient and steady-state performance. Experimental validation on a dSPACE DS1104 real time platform compares the performance of PI, PR, and PIR controllers. Results reveal that the conventional PI controller fails to sustain post-fault operation, while the adaptive PR controller enhances system continuity and dynamicrecovery. The proposed adaptive PIR controller further mitigates torque pulsations, reducing torque ripple from over 60% (PI-based) to approximately 10%, demonstrating significant improvement in fault-tolerant performance and robustness. This approach contributes to the development of reliable, self-healing industrial drive subsystems for next-generation smart manufacturing systems.

title: Blockchain-Assisted Meta-Learning for Efficient and Reliable Authentication in IoV
authors: Xiaoying Qiu, Guangxu Zhao, Xujie He, Jinwei Yu, Wenbao Jiang, Zhaozhong Guo, Maozhi Xu
abstract: Considering the rapid variations in frequently changing environment and the broadcast nature of wireless signals, security authentication plays a crucial role in ensuring the security of internet of vehicles (IoV) communications. Existing authentication schemes in IoV suffer from two main limitations: First, protocol-based authentication causes high latency and heavy cryptographic overhead when dealing with numerous concurrent requests. Second, although edge computing-assisted methods reduce cloud communication latency, the ability to support model adaptation across environments remains limited. To address these challenges, a blockchain-assisted meta-learning (BAML) authentication scheme is proposed for providing security authentication protection in IoV. Specifically, a meta-learning algorithm is designed to collaboratively learn the device/location/channel-related feature of vehicles from source environments and then to verify their identities. During the movement of vehicles, a blockchain module is proposed to guide the new environment to inherit the most optimal authentication knowledge from the meta-learning knowledge base and achieve high performance even with limited data. The BAML scheme is designed for reliable collaboration and continuous protections in IoV. Extensive experiments are conducted to validate the effectiveness of BAML. When given 9 samples, the BAML of new environments reaches 99.7%, surpassing other competitive baselines.

title: Enhancing Software Interoperability Through Virtual Knowledge Graphs from Object-Oriented APIs
authors: Maximilian Weigand, Felix Gehlhoff, Alexander Fay
abstract: In engineering disciplines such as mechanical or automation engineering, data exchange between different software often relies on non-standardized interfaces. While Semantic Web technologies (SWTs) offer solutions for efficient and versatile data exchange, the majority of software in engineering lack interfaces based on these technologies. Previous research has explored approaches to abstract structured data from external sources as virtual knowledge graphs (VKGs). In this work, we propose an approach to create VKGs from data available via the APIs of engineering software, enabling the querying of engineering data through SWTs and thus facilitating standardized data exchange. We first mathematically introduce the components of APIs of object-oriented software, including classes, their hierarchical relationships, attributes, and instances. We then define formulas to derive the triples of the VKG representing the components, as well as resulting triples according to RDFS entailment rules. Finally, we define a procedure based on the aforementioned formulas, which enables querying the VKG using triple patterns. This provides access to the VKG representing the software-internal data without materialization, in line with the concept of virtual. We provide a general implementation of the approach, supporting triple pattern and SPARQL queries, and a software-specific adaption for a particular engineering software. Using this, we demonstrate the capabilities of the approach through an industrial use case. The performance characteristics of the approach are evaluated by analyzing query execution times and scaling behavior across different query types and graph sizes, in comparison with equivalent materialized graphs.

title: Interpretable Merging-Vehicle Acceleration Prediction via a Decoder-Only Transformer and Attention Map Clustering
authors: Hyunseok Oh, Jooyong Lee, Junghwa Kim
abstract: This paper proposes a decoder-only Transformer model for analyzing and clustering vehicle-to-vehicle interactions in highway merge zones. Leveraging deep learning, the model captures complex nonlinear relationships in time-series interaction data. To address the limited interpretability of neural networks, internal attention maps are clustered to reveal how the model allocates focus across time, providing insights into the temporal dynamics of merging behaviors. The proposed approach is evaluated against established acceleration-prediction methods, including LSTM, GRU, and the intelligent driver model (IDM), and achieves consistently lower prediction error among the data-driven models. Furthermore, by comparing cluster-specific differences in speed and spacing, the analysis uncovers distinct merging behavior patterns and validates the model’s ability to differentiate merge strategies. The attention-based interpretation highlights critical interaction moments that reflect driver decision processes during merging. Overall, the results demonstrate that the proposed framework effectively combines predictive performance with interpretable behavior analysis for traffic interactions in highway merge zones.

title: Design and Experimental Validation of a Safe Control Strategy for Reconfigurable Batteries
authors: Iman Ebrahimi, Ricardo de Castro
publish: IEEE Transactions on Control Systems Technology
abstract: In this article, we present a novel control strategy for optimizing the management of reconfigurable batteries, particularly in electric vehicles (EVs) and energy storage systems. Our approach uniquely integrates control allocation (CA) with control barrier functions (CBF) to enhance operational efficiency while enforcing electrothermal safety constraints. Specifically, the proposed control scheme regulates the output voltage and ensures state-of-charge (SoC) balancing across battery modules, addressing the common weakest-module problem. Additionally, it dynamically adjusts power distribution to provide over-temperature protection, mitigating the risk of thermal runaway. Our feasibility analysis establishes the conditions under which the CBF-based safety constraints are satisfied, ensuring the existence of feasible control actions. Furthermore, we define comprehensive performance metrics to evaluate and compare the controller’s effectiveness. This includes CBF gain tuning based on feasibility results. We perform scalability analysis, demonstrating the controller’s effectiveness in systems with a large number of modules, which is critical for EV applications where computational efficiency is paramount. Finally, experimental validation on a small-scale prototype showcases the practical capability of our CBF-based optimal controller.

title: CSTNet: A Cross-Scale Transformer Network for Singing Melody Extraction
authors: Jianbin Chen, Hao Xu, Zhengwei Peng, Yue Li
abstract: Singing melody extraction from polyphonic music is a complex but important task in music information retrieval. Most existing models struggle with adaptive multi-scale feature extraction and long-range dependency modeling, often resulting in common artifacts such as octave errors and pitch fragmentation. To address this, we propose the Cross-Scale Transformer Network (CSTNet), a novel deep learning architecture that dynamically captures and fuses multi-scale temporal and spectral features. The CSTNet introduces two key components: the Multi scale Time-Frequency Aggregation (MF-TFA) module for adaptive local feature representation across resolutions, and Feature Cross Transformer Block (FCTB), which enables explicit cross scale interaction through a global channel-wise cross-attention mechanism. Experimental results show that our proposed method outperforms five compared state-of-the-art methods, achieving overall accuracy scores of 87.3%, 90.5%, and 77.4% on the ADC 2004, MIREX 05, and MEDLEY DB datasets, respectively. Visualization results demonstrate that CSTNet effectively reduces octave errors.

title: Exploring Generative AI for Mitigating Digital Twin Deviation in Secure Vehicular Edge Computing
authors: Xuan Li, Wanting Wang, Pengyi Liu, Tianqing Zhou, Haibin Xia
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Communications Society
abstract: Digital twin (DT) has emerged as a potent tool for intelligent resource management in vehicular edge computing (VEC), and it marks a pivotal advancement in VEC via real-time physical entity mapping and state perception. However, due to the complex nature of dynamic state synchronization and multi-dimensional resource coupling in VEC, few existing studies have considered DT deviation and its impacts on network energy consumption and secure transmission. To address these issues, this paper first formulates a collaborative optimization problem integrating DT and generative artificial intelligence (GenAI), where GenAI is embedded in the DT model for real-time deviation calibration, and combined with non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) achieves efficient co-channel interference suppression; meanwhile, the computation model covers local, cache and multi-step offloading scenarios while deriving latency and energy consumption expressions with security overhead considered. Then, an improved marine predators algorithm (IMPA) is proposed to solve the above mixed-integer nonlinear programming (MINLP), which introduces a competitive update mechanism to dynamically balance global exploration and local exploitation via real-time fitness feedback. Finally, theoretical analysis and experimental results show that the proposed IMPA can converge with low complexity, and compared with existing algorithms, it achieves 83.3% improvement in total energy consumption reduction and 75.3% enhancement in latency stability.

title: Adaptive Fuzzy Logic-Based SMO Utilizing Higher Order Soft-Sign Function With ROA Tuned PI Gains for Sensorless PMSM Drive
authors: Rohit Raj, Pramod Agarwal, Sharmili Das
abstract: This article presents an advanced sensorless control strategy for permanent magnet synchronous motors (PMSMs) that integrates optimal proportional integral (PI) controller tuning via the remora optimization algorithm (ROA) with robust speed estimation using a fuzzy-adaptive higher-order soft-sign sliding mode observer (SMO). The ROA, a population-based optimizer characterized by low computational complexity and fast convergence, is employed in an offline optimization mode to tune the PI gains for the speed, direct-axis (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol{i}_{\boldsymbol{d}}$</tex-math></inline-formula>), and quadrature-axis (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol{i}_{\boldsymbol{q}}$</tex-math></inline-formula>) current loops within a field-oriented control (FOC) framework. Compared to particle swarm optimization (PSO) and genetic algorithm (GA)-based tuning, the ROA achieves approximately 50% faster convergence with fewer control parameters and stable global optimization behavior. The proposed SMO incorporates a higher order soft-sign switching function whose parameters are adaptively tuned by a fuzzy logic controller (FLC) using Gaussian bell shaped membership functions, enabling real time adjustment of the function’s slope and smoothness. Experimental validation on a TMS320F28379D DSP-based PMSM drive demonstrates a maximum steady state speed ripple of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol{\pm}$</tex-math></inline-formula>0.5 rpm, a peak overshoot of 2.5 rpm, a settling time of 3.85 s within the 300–1500 rpm range, and approximately 14.2% improvement in settling time compared to the sigmoid-based observers approach. The integrated ROA–FLC–SMO framework thus delivers improved robustness, adaptability, and computational efficiency for real-time PMSM drives.

title: TD3-Enhanced Adaptive Active Disturbance Rejection Control for Bidirectional DC-DC Converter in Photovoltaic-Battery Hybrid Microgrids
authors: Yuhong Zhang, Xiuhui Peng
abstract: This paper addresses the stability and reliability issues associated with the application of linear active disturbance rejection control (LADRC) in hybrid PV-battery microgrids. A hierarchical control strategy tailored for bidirectional DC-DC converter in the system is proposed. The strategy comprises an outer voltage regulation loop implemented with an enhanced LADRC and an inner current tracking loop driven by a proportional-integral (PI) controller. Specifically, the traditional LADRC is enhanced via an improved linear extended state observer, which achieves separate compensation for low-order and high-order disturbances. Additionally, the observer parameters are optimized in real time based on the Twin Delayed Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient (TD3) algorithm. Finally, simulations and experiments under multiple operating conditions are conducted to validate the proposed control strategy, demonstrating its superior performance over double closed-loop PI control and traditional LADRC.

title: CapsFormer: A Dual-Stream Causal-Aware Capsule-Transformer Network for EMG Signal Representation Learning
authors: Pengpai Wang, Tiantian Xie, Yueying Zhou, Peiliang Gong, Wei Sun, Xiaorui Zhang, Rosa H. M. Chan
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Electromyography (EMG) signals are widely applied in prosthetic control, rehabilitation training, and human-machine interaction. This places stringent requirements on gesture recognition algorithms to balance long-range temporal modeling with local pose invariance. Existing approaches typically trade off between local and global features and lack causally consistent interpretability, resulting in insufficient generalization across subjects and sessions. To address these shortcomings, we propose a novel dual-stream causal Capsule-Transformer network (CapsFormer). In the Transformer stream, we employ a “causal attention” in the self-attention mechanism to explicitly block all future information, ensuring that each time-step representation depends solely on itself and prior signals; in the Capsule stream, we leverage dynamic routing to capture local part-whole pose vectors, enhancing robustness against electrode shifts and muscle deformations. The two streams' features are then integrated in a fusion module and trained end-to-end. To validate the model's effectiveness, we evaluate it on a multi-subject dataset; results demonstrate that CapsFormer outperforms state-of-the-art models in recognition accuracy, cross-subject robustness, and interpretability. This work not only offers a new paradigm for efficient EMG signal representation but also supports causally consistent temporal signal analysis and interpretable deep learning methods, bearing significant implications for intelligent prosthetic control and human-machine interfaces.
