title: Investigating the Properties of a New Vertical 4H-SiC Photoconductive Semiconductor Switch With a Double-Side Epitaxial Structure
authors: Wenfeng Liu, Jianqiang Yuan, Chongbiao Luan, Jiangling Mao, Ping Cai, Longfei Xiao, Hongwei Liu, Xiang Fu, Xianchao Yu, Fangbo Zheng
abstract: In this work, a new vertical vanadium-compensated semi-insulating 4H silicon carbide (VCSI 4H-SiC) photoconductive semiconductor switch (PCSS) with the heavily doped interlayers between electrodes and substrate is proposed to further enhance the operating electric field. For 532 nm, 10-ns laser excitation, the numerical simulation was conducted to characterize the static and dynamic electrical performance of the proposed device. The simulation results confirm that the introduced heavily doped interlayers effectively homogenize the internal electric field distribution within the 4H-SiC substrate and, more notably, reduce the dark-state peak electric field by as much as 93.91% relative to the device without interlayers, exhibiting superior high-voltage characteristics. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed device achieves a maximum operating electric field of 300 kV/cm, representing a 50%–87.5% enhancement over existing PCSSs.

title: AirSpy: An Air-pinch Keystroke Inference Attack on Virtual Keyboards in VR Systems
authors: Luo Zhou, Jiusong Luo, Xueying Gong, Jiaming Pei, Wei Liu, Huixiang Wen
abstract: Consumer VR headsets increasingly support text entry via air-pinch gestures on virtual keyboards, yet app-visible telemetry can inadvertently expose keystrokes. We present AirSpy, a permission-lean application-layer side channel that combines (i) VR hand-tracking joint pose with unit-quaternion rotations and (ii) lightweight per-frame PAL counters (e.g., draw calls and frame timing). Our key insight is that each keystroke induces short, repeatable PAL spikes/dips that align in time with subtle quaternion dynamics of the pinching hand. Based on this complementarity, we build a two-stage pipeline: a PAL-driven segmentation module anchors candidate keypress windows, followed by attribution-guided feature selection and a lightweight Transformer–DNN decoder for key inference. We implement AirSpy on Meta Quest 2 and Meta Quest 3 and evaluate it with 10 participants on a 29-key virtual keyboard (55k labeled frames). In foreground mode, AirSpy reaches 93.56% Top-1 accuracy with 92.8% segmentation recall; under background throttling, accuracy remains about 90.1%. Cross-device transfer between Quest 2 and Quest 3 maintains about 85–86% accuracy. The runtime overhead is small (about 11–13 ms added latency with under 3 FPS impact). Finally, we quantify practical mitigations, including API rate limiting and PAL counter sanitization, and summarize security–utility trade-offs to help platform designers better balance responsiveness and privacy.

title: Active Harmonic Voltage Injection Facilitating Application of Impedance Measurement-Based Protection in Microgrids_supp1-3668047.docx
authors: Longhua Mu
abstract: A capable and cost-effective protection scheme is essential for the reliable operation of a microgrid. Conventional impedance measurement-based protection is hindered by shorter line lengths, lower line reactance-to-resistance ratios, and fault ride-through (FRT) of inverter-interfaced distributed generators (IIDGs) in microgrids. They are prone to malfunction due to the remote end infeed current during non-metallic faults. This paper addresses this challenge through the coordination of control and protection. IIDGs are configured to actively inject a small harmonic voltage component into the microgrid after fault while coping with FRT requirements using a dual-frequency controller. A hybrid injection activation criterion is embedded to ensure coordinated harmonic injection and equal participation from all IIDGs. Consequently, a uniform harmonic-frequency voltage potential can be generated throughout the microgrid, and its impact on IIDGs' FRT is minimized. The feasibility of the proposed scheme is verified on a hardware-in-the-loop (HIL) experimental platform, and its enhancement to protection performance is validated through theoretical and simulation studies. It is revealed that the proposed control scheme can significantly reduce the fault location error and facilitate the application of single-ended impedance measurement-based protection in microgrids.

title: Cardiology-Chat: A Multi-LLMs powered System for Cardiac Diagnostic Reasoning and Clinical Support
authors: Zhibin Yang, Chuanyue Chen, Seedahmed S. Mahmoud, Xuerui Tan, Yequn Chen, Qiang Fang
publish: IEEE Journal of Translational Engineering in Health and Medicine
abstract: Cardiovascular diseases are a leading global cause of death, but their accurate diagnosis remains challenging. While Large Language Models (LLMs) show promise in assisting disease diagnosis in general, their adoption in cardiology is hindered by three critical limitations: hallucination, inadequate domain-specific reasoning, and restricted knowledge coverage. To overcome these barriers, we developed Cardiology-Chat, an LLM-based system specifically tailored for cardiology. The system employs a three-step main reasoning framework: (1) parsing user queries with Llama 3.1 8B-instruct to extract key clinical information, (2) retrieving evidence from the knowledge base via Retrieval-augmented generation (RAG), and (3) generating diagnostic conclusions using the fine-tuned Llama model. Two critical components have been developed to support the system's functionality. The first is a specialized cardiovascular vector knowledge base, constructed from multiple data sources to enhance the RAG subsystem. The second is a Chain-of-Thought–augmented dataset designed to strengthen the LLM’s in-depth reasoning capabilities. In addition, multiple LLMs were adopted to mitigate the possible "self-consistency" bias. Experiments on public cardiology QA and real clinical cases demonstrated significant performance improvements, achieving 0.796 accuracy and 0.807 F1 respectively.

title: Efficient Object Detection and Depth Estimation Algorithms for Transportation Scenarios
authors: Hua Guo, Qinghua Zhai, Mingshang Lu, Changyu Jiang
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Image, Signal Processing and Communication Technology (ISPCT)
abstract: Object detection and depth estimation are fundamental tasks for autonomous driving systems. In traffic scenarios, existing object detectors often exhibit low recall rates when processing distant targets. Furthermore, the inherent depth ambiguity of monocular vision limits its application in three-dimensional spatial perception tasks. To address these issues, this paper proposes a collaborative perception framework that integrates improved YOLO11 detection (YOLO-DM) with depth estimation. The YOLO-DM network builds upon YOLO11 by introducing a novel C2PSA-MSDA module to expand the receptive field and enhance object features, while integrating a Dynamic Detection Head (DyHead) to improve scale robustness. Furthermore, the YOLO-DM network is combined with the PSMNet stereo matching network to achieve efficient acquisition of target depth information. Evaluation on the KITTI dataset demonstrates that compared to the baseline, YOLO-DM improves mAP@0.5 by 2.2% and mAP@[0.5:0.95] by 2.7%, while reducing computational complexity and parameter count by 4.9% and 6.7%, respectively. The proposed framework significantly enhances perception accuracy while maintaining high model efficiency, offering a highly promising perception solution for autonomous driving systems.

title: Dual-band frequency selective rasorber with absorption effect in the X band
authors: Fan He, Zhaowang Cao, Lijie Chen, Gengjiang Yao, Xunzhi Ding
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Communication, Sensing and Electromagnetics (ICSE)
abstract: To adapt to the increasingly complex electromagnetic environment, a dual-polarization dual-band frequency selective rasorber is proposed. The top layer of the design is a lossy layer, which is made up of surface-mount inductors and capacitors, as well as winding slots to achieve dual-band transmission, and chip resistors to achieve broadband absorption. The design consists of two identical lossless layers. The lossless layers are composed of square ring gaps and circular ring gaps, achieving the effect of wave transmission within the passband and reflection outside the passband. The proposed design has a wave-transmitting effect within 2.96GHz-3.63GHz and 5.04GHz-5.66GHz, while achieving a wave-absorbing effect within 7GHz-13.34GHz, covering the X band.

title: HLTSA: A Hierarchical-Updated Tree-Seed Algorithm with Dynamic Benchmark Selection and Mean Position Guidance
authors: Yueqi Xu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Computer Science, Electronic Information Engineering and Intelligent Control Technology (CEI)
abstract: This paper presents the Hierarchical Levy-enhanced Tree Seed Algorithm (HLTSA) to address limitations of the traditional Tree Seed Algorithm (TSA). HLTSA integrates hierarchical Levy flight and dynamic benchmark selection to balance global exploration and local exploitation, overcoming premature convergence and insufficient diversity. It adopts Kent Chaotic Mapping for initial population initialization to enhance randomness and ergodicity. A differentiated seed generation mechanism, combining the global best individual and population average position with fitness ranking and random threshold, improves optimization accuracy and convergence robustness. Comparative experiments with TSA, STSA, GWO, EEFO, and GA on CEC2014 benchmark functions show HLTSA outperforms competitors in solution accuracy, convergence speed, and robustness across unimodal, multimodal, and hybrid functions. HLTSA effectively mitigates TSA's core drawbacks and is promising for complex high-dimensional optimization problems and real-world applications.

title: Modeling and Optimization Design Method for Curved Conformal Frequency Selective Surfaces Based on Adaptive Spatial Variant Lattice Algorithm
authors: Huaiqian Xu, Hui Chen, Zhanye Chen, Yao Zong, Xiaoyang Zhou
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Intelligent Communication, Sensing and Electromagnetics (ICSE)
abstract: To address the urgent demand for conformal integration of electromagnetic devices on complex curved surfaces with high-performance in modern wireless communication and radar systems, as well as the core challenge that traditional planar array conformal methods are prone to causing periodic structure distortion and electromagnetic performance degradation, this paper proposes an integrated optimization theory and design workflow for curved-surface conformal frequency selective surfaces (FSS) based on an improved spatial variant lattice (SVL) algorithm.Rooted in Floquet periodic system theory, the proposed theory converts the curved-surface conformal problem into an optimal reconstruction task of harmonic vector fields via multi-order spatial harmonic decomposition. Its core innovations lie in introducing a gradient descent iterative algorithm to realize adaptive correction of key spatial variables of the array, and proposing an adaptive regional optimization strategy. By partitioning the array aperture into functional regions (core region/transition region), this strategy achieves dynamic balance between directional response accuracy and periodic structure stability. Finally, high-precision conformal array apertures are generated through harmonic superposition and binarization processing.To verify the method’s effectiveness, three groups of control arrays (11×11 planar array, direct-projection curved-surface array, and SVL-optimized curved-surface array) were constructed using rectangular patch FSS elements, with full-wave simulations conducted in HFSS. Results demonstrate that the paraboloidal conformal array optimized by the SVL algorithm can stably maintain resonant characteristics around 12 GHz, whereas the traditional direct projection method leads to a complete disappearance of resonant points, fully validating the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

title: Research on smoke screen delivery methods based on composite algorithms
authors: NaNa Du, ChenYu Yue, Qi Wang, QunXiang Wei, ZhengZhang Lu
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Human-Computer Interaction and Robotics (AIHCIR)
abstract: Smoke screen jammers, characterized by low cost and high cost-effectiveness, form aerosol clouds via chemical combustion or explosion to shield targets and interfere with enemy missiles. Currently, drones enable their fixed-point deployment and timed detonation. This paper focuses on optimizing drone-based smoke screen jammer deployment across multiple scenarios, with core contributions centered on algorithm performance enhancements. The model incorporates three key algorithmic modules: a dynamically adaptive geometric judgment module with a dynamic step-size triggering mechanism to reduce redundant calculations, a discretized time analysis module with dynamic interval compression to balance computational accuracy and efficiency, and an interval extraction module with dynamic differencing and merging to minimize invalid operations. The algorithm's strong adaptability to complex combat environments and superior computational efficiency provide critical technical support for the engineering application of smoke screen jamming technology, addressing the disconnect between traditional models and practical combat scenarios.

title: Research on Multi-Object Tracking Algorithms Combining Pedestrian Appearance Features under Occlusion Conditions
authors: Yang Shao, Ziliang Du, Bo Liu, Xilin Zhang, Chi Huang, Jiangong Wang
publish: 2025 International Symposium on AI-Driven Image Processing and Computer Vision Technology (AIPCVT)
abstract: This study proposes an occlusion-robust multiobject tracking (MOT) algorithm designed to mitigate frequent identity switches induced by degraded pedestrian appearance features in occluded scenarios. The proposed method first develops a deep pedestrian appearance feature extraction network with global, local, and mask branches, which is jointly trained using triplet loss and cross-entropy loss to enhance feature discriminability for distinguishing individual pedestrians. Feature similarity is quantified via cosine similarity, which better aligns with the angular relationships in high-dimensional feature spaces compared to Euclidean metrics. Second, a joint association cost matrix is constructed by integrating motion information (IoU distance derived from Kalman-filtered trajectory predictions) with appearance information enabling high-precision detection-to-trajectory matching through a two-stage Hungarian algorithm framework. To address dynamic occlusion and posture variations, the appearance template library is incrementally updated, with adaptive updates triggered by significant posture changes. Experimental results on the MOT16 benchmark dataset demonstrate that the proposed algorithm achieves a state-of-theart MOTA score of 67.9%, significantly outperforming conventional methods and validating the efficacy of the joint appearance-motion strategy in enhancing tracking stability and accuracy under occlusion conditions. This work advances occlusion-robust MOT by integrating multi-branch feature learning with motion-aware appearance fusion, offering a scalable solution for real-world applications like intelligent surveillance and autonomous driving where dense occlusions are prevalent, and provides new insights into synergistic design of feature extraction and association mechanisms for conferencerelated technical fields (e.g., computer vision, intelligent transportation).

title: Ancillary Service Market Mechanisms and Value Realization of Regulating Resources in Modern Power Systems: International Comparisons and Implications
authors: Wang Henan, Xu Nan, Wei Kun, Zhang Xinyue, Liu Mengjie, Wang Wei, Li Yixin
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power System and Renewable Energy (PSRE)
abstract: With the advancement of the “Carbon Neutrality” strategy and the rapid expansion of renewable energy capacity, China's power system faces operational stability challenges due to the volatility of new energy sources. The ancillary services market has emerged as a key mechanism for optimizing resource allocation and realizing value. This paper systematically reviews the operational mechanisms of domestic and international ancillary services markets, focusing on analyzing mechanism innovations and resource value realization pathways in market segmentation areas across provinces like Shandong and Shanxi. It compares these with mature international markets in the United States, Germany, and the United Kingdom. The study reveals existing issues in China's market and proposes optimization pathways drawing on international experience, including implementing performance-based pricing and refining customer-side cost-sharing mechanisms. These measures will strongly support the safe, stable, and high-quality development of the new power system.

title: Research on Hot-Line Replacement Technology and Temporary Support System for Main Member of DC Transmission Line Based on Load Transfer
authors: Yangzhi Wei, Kuoteng Sun
publish: 2025 2nd international conference on DC technologies and systems (DCTS)
abstract: Aiming at the engineering challenge of emergency repair for damaged tower members of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{+ 5 0 0 k V}$</tex> DC transmission lines in complex terrain due to geological disasters, this paper researches and proposes a hot-line replacement solution integrating systematic load transfer theory and digital real-time monitoring technologies. The core of the solution lies in constructing a complete temporary support system to safely reconstruct the load-bearing path of the tower, incorporating a UAV-based tilt monitoring system and intelligent tension alarm devices for load-bearing tools, thereby achieving visual and data-driven control over the entire operation process. The paper elaborates on the mechanical models, digital monitoring principles, and safety coordination mechanisms of this comprehensive technical system. Combined with a practical case of a tension tower member bending in the karst mountainous area of Hechi, Guangxi, it fully presents the entire process from theoretical calculation and intelligent perception to precise implementation. Application results show that this technical system not only successfully achieved the hot-line replacement of the main member but also ensured the entire process of load transfer and structural changes was knowable and controllable through real-time data feedback, with the maximum tower tilt change controlled within 0.08° and the error of tension monitoring data less than 5 % compared to theoretical values, providing an innovative and highly reliable technical paradigm for the intelligent operation, maintenance, and emergency repair of EHV DC transmission lines.

title: YOLOv8-Dynamicatss-Based Method for Extracting Structural Component Information in Bridge Engineering
authors: Xinxin Ye, Chuanjian Wang, Zhiyou Cheng, Kongbin Ou, Zhigang Wu, Liang Yin
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Computer Science, Electronic Information Engineering and Intelligent Control Technology (CEI)
abstract: To address the challenges of inefficient retrieval and reuse in bridge engineering design drawings due to their large information volume and complex structures, this study proposes an intelligent key information extraction method based on deep learning. First, we introduce the DynamicATSS (Adaptive Tag Assignment Strategy) into the YOLOv8 model, which dynamically adjusts IoU thresholds for targets of different scales to improve dense target detection. Second, we optimize boundary box regression using the UIoU loss function to enhance the detection accuracy of multi-scale structural components in drawings. Third, we employ the VI-LayoutXLM model for semantic parsing of detected regions, assigning engineering semantic labels to text through semantic entity recognition (SER). Finally, an automated extraction workflow is established to achieve structured output of critical information. Experimental results demonstrate that the method achieves a detection performance of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 7. 2 \%} \boldsymbol{(} \mathbf{m A P} {@} 0.5$</tex>) on a self-built bridge drawing dataset, effectively supporting the digital storage and intelligent retrieval of bridge design knowledge.

title: Impact of Heterogeneity in Electric Vehicle Fast Charging Profiles on Queuing and Grid Load
authors: Hannah Morin, Aeka Chatra, Jay Whitacre, Jeremy Michalek
publish: 2026 IEEE Electrical Energy Storage Applications and Technologies Conference (EESAT)
abstract: Increased electric vehicle adoption has expanded the number of unique fast charging profiles, further complicating infrastructure planning. In this study we characterize heterogeneity in real-world electric vehicle (EV) fast charging profiles across different vehicle models to identify key factors and to suggest implications for future profile design. We create a dataset from publicly available information then build a queuing model to understand throughput and electricity demand on high travel days. We quantify uncertainty in the number of EVs that can move through a charging station by comparing a Monte Carlo simulation to the deterministic throughput of a single repeated fast charging profile for each vehicle charged. Our findings show heterogeneity is significant for a 12 hour charging window, varying from 14 to 57 vehicles. Modeling diverse profiles or ensuring proper representation of the EV population should be considered when modeling infrastructure.

title: Application Technology of Real-Time Situational Detection for Mobile Low-Altitude UAVs Along Coastal Areas
authors: Chao Liang, Hui Han, Mei Wang, Jiahe Xu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Computer Science, Electronic Information Engineering and Intelligent Control Technology (CEI)
abstract: In coastal offshore areas (including mountains, beaches, sea surfaces, and high-rise buildings), real-time monitoring and data collection of UAVs are conducted to achieve full-coverage detection (no monitoring blind spots), accurate identification (parsing key information such as UAV identity and flight status), real–time positioning (dynamic tracking of flight trajectories), and rapid data transmission within the test area. Meanwhile, all monitoring data is synchronized to the situational display platform for situation presentation, constructing an integrated complete data link of “detection, identification, reporting, and display”. The system possesses full-coverage, and non-dead-angle situational awareness capabilities for low-altitude UAVs within horizontal distance 5 km.

title: Blind Source-Separation-Based Method for Suppressing Radar Mainlobe Deceptive Jamming via Range-Domain Sparsity-Based Screening
authors: Yilin Han, Yiming Zhang, Wei Jing
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Computer Science, Electronic Information Engineering and Intelligent Control Technology (CEI)
abstract: To suppress mainlobe deceptive jamming in array radars, we propose a blind source separation method that exploits range-domain sparsity-based screening. The beamformed received signals are pulse compressed, and high-energy range gates selected by an energy threshold are used to construct the observation matrix. After whitening, a joint diagonalization procedure is employed to estimate the separation matrix, which is subsequently applied to all range cells to recover the target and jamming components. The proposed method maintains robust separation performance even under increased signal correlation or when the directions of arrival of the target and interference are closely spaced. Its effectiveness is demonstrated through numerical simulations.

title: Development of Multimedia Tests in Electrical Technologies in Online Learning Environment
authors: Dmytro Babenko, Nataliia Dotsenko, Olena Gorbenko
publish: 2024 IEEE 6th International Conference on Modern Electrical and Energy System (MEES)
abstract: The development of multimedia tests in the conditions of the online learning environment provides plenty of opportunities for accessing knowledge in electrical technologies. The article outlines the main aspects of the development and implementation of the multimedia tests in electrical technologies, their technological and methodological features. There are outlined the pedagogical technology of development and implementation of multimedia online tests in online learning environment. Also, it is presented the scheme of the combining the discipline "Electrical technologies" with multimedia tests. There are presented the video, 3D, graphical, animated types of tests. According to the proposed technology there are developed the criteria of evaluation of the developed tests: motivational, pedagogical, technological, methodological. On the basis of the developed criteria there were made estimation of the efficiency of the developed multimedia tests. Also, there were made an analysis of the levels of knowledge of students in Electrical Technologies and estimation of the efficiency of the proposed technology that was statistically tested.

title: Topic-Enhanced Instruction Tuning for Automatic Knowledge Graph Construction
authors: Xiaoyu Sun, Ke Liang, Sihang Zhou, Jie Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Knowledge Graph (ICKG)
abstract: Existing knowledge graph construction (KGC) methods often rely on extensive manual annotation, confined to specific domains and limiting their adaptability to diverse tasks. Language models (LMs) have recently demonstrated exceptional potential for KGC owing to their superior text comprehension and generalization capabilities, addressing the limitations of traditional methods. We propose a topic-enhanced instruction tuning approach, where an instruction-tuned LM extracts structured knowledge from unstructured text. Text topics predicted by deep learning models are incorporated into instructions to guide the LM in identifying domain-relevant entities and relations. Experimental results demonstrate that our approach significantly improves triplet extraction F1-score by 1.23% compared to topic-agnostic baselines, validating the efficacy of topic-enhanced instruction tuning for automatic KGC.

title: An Adaptive SOC Virtual Inertia Control Strategy for Receiving-End GFM-MMCs with DC-Side Battery Energy Storage
authors: Wenkun Chen, Xiaoling Xiong, Chenlong Wang
publish: 2025 2nd international conference on DC technologies and systems (DCTS)
abstract: This paper presents a State-of-Charge (SOC)-aware virtual inertia control strategy for grid-forming modular multilevel converters (GFM-MMCs) serving a receiving-end weak AC grid. Unlike typical micro-grid applications, the receiving-end MMC acts as the main supporter for the weak grid, where abrupt support loss due to battery depletion can trigger severe system-level instability. The link connects a sending-end PV-based islanded AC system to a receiving-end weak AC grid. A battery energy storage system (BESS) is interfaced with the DC link via an MMC-based DC/DC converter. To address the conflict between frequency support and energy constraints, an adaptive control scheme featuring a trapezoidal SOC-inertia profile is proposed. This mechanism maintains maximum virtual inertia within a nominal SOC range while dynamically decreasing the inertia coefficient as the SOC approaches its critical limits. Furthermore, a hard-constraint SOC protection scheme is implemented to prevent battery over-depletion. Time-domain simulations under diverse SOC conditions verify that the proposed strategy sustains the frequency support capability of conventional fixed-inertia designs, while effectively mitigating SOC depletion and preventing the violation of critical SOC constraints.

title: Renewable Energy-Based Charging Infrastructure for Electric Vehicles: A Review
authors: Farzad Razaghi
publish: 2026 IEEE Electrical Energy Storage Applications and Technologies Conference (EESAT)
abstract: The global transition toward electric mobility highlights the urgent need for sustainable and intelligent charging infrastructure powered by renewable energy sources. This paper presents a review of the technical, economic, and operational challenges associated with renewable-based electric vehicle charging systems. Core focus areas include integration of recent energy storage technologies and adaptive energy management frameworks enhanced by artificial intelligence, power quality, and grid stability. The study further examines the role of smart technologies such as Vehicle-to-Grid (V2G) and artificial intelligence-driven control strategies that enhance flexibility, cost-efficiency, and responsiveness. By synthesizing recent advancements and multidisciplinary insights, this review aims to guide the development of scalable, inclusive, and environmentally responsible electric vehicle charging ecosystems.

title: Weekly Refined Unit Commitment for Provincial Power Systems with High Penetration of Renewables
authors: Kunyu Wang, Yixuan He, Kai Jiang, Jie Huang, Zhen Wang, Nian Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power System and Renewable Energy (PSRE)
abstract: In recent years, China's provincial power grids have entered a phase of high-proportion renewable energy penetration. Traditional weekly unit commitment models, lacking scenario adaptability and insufficient modeling refinement, often fail to balance renewable energy's periodic and cumulative fluctuations with multi-resource long-time-horizon coordinated dispatching requirements. This leads to unit operation inefficiencies and inadequate renewable energy consumption. To address this issue, this paper proposes a weekly refined unit commitment optimization method tailored for provincial power systems with high-proportion renewable energy. Targeting renewable energy's high installed capacity and generation volume, the method integrates electricity spot market clearing rules, refines modeling time granularity to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 5}$</tex> minutes to capture short-term output fluctuations of renewable energy, and covers wind, photovoltaic, hydropower, thermal power, and energy storage, achieving comprehensive optimization of unit start-ups and shut-downs states and output levels all week. A case study was conducted on a representative Chinese provincial power grid, where both renewable energy capacity and generation share rank top nationwide. Results show the proposed model not only reduces intra-day unit start-ups and shut-downs frequency, boosts power grid periodic reserve adjustment margin, and cuts windphotovoltaic curtailment, but also provides clear operational boundaries for day-ahead optimal scheduling. Ultimately, it offers reliable weekly operation support for power grid multi-time-scale coordinated dispatching.

title: HUSHHH: An Immersive 3D Puzzle-Solving Game for Sign Language Learning
authors: Jia Min Ng, Luke Chee Chien Lee, Ying Mei Leong
publish: 2025 International Conference on Applied Artificial Intelligence, Data Engineering and Sciences (ICAIDES)
abstract: This paper introduces HUSHHH, an immersive 3D escape-adventure game that reconceptualizes sign language acquisition as a contextual survival challenge. In contrast to conventional vocabulary-driven tools, HUSHHH integrates Bahasa Isyarat Malaysia (BIM) gestures into its core mechanics, compelling players to decipher signs to advance through puzzles. The game was developed using Unity and C#, with custom Blender animations enabling real-time feedback. A comparative evaluation involving 46 participants revealed that HUSHHH outperformed an established platform (Lingvano) across key metrics, achieving superior scores on a five-point scale for learning retention (4.80 vs. 2.09), empathy building (4.63 vs. 2.37), and engagement (3.93 vs. 3.26). These quantitative outcomes statistically validated ($p\lt .001$), position immersive gameplay as a highly promising and inclusive paradigm for sign language education.

title: A Preliminary Investigation of a Mathematics Educational Game (Math Planet) for Supporting Slow Learners in Mathematics: Exploring the Potential of AI Integration
authors: Wong Joe Ying, Danakorn Nincarean Eh Phon, Nor Saradatul Akmar Zulkifli, Suhaizal Hashim, Nor Hidayah Che Lah, Nor Hannani Izzati Abdullah
publish: 2025 International Conference on Applied Artificial Intelligence, Data Engineering and Sciences (ICAIDES)
abstract: Traditional classrooms can disadvantage students who learn math slower, widening the achievement gap. This study explored the potential of “Math Planet,” a newly developed educational math game, to bridge this gap for slow learners in Standard 1 mathematics. A preliminary round of user testing was conducted to explore how Math Planet could support learning among slow learners in mathematics. Three Standard 1 students with diagnosed mathematical learning difficulties engaged with the game’s core modules, which focused on sorting, matching, and basic question-answering. All participants reported enjoying the experience, and two out of three indicated that the game improved their confidence in solving math problems. These early observations point to Math Planet’s promise as a supplementary learning tool. Additionally, this paper outlines future directions for integrating Artificial Intelligence (AI) into the game. The proposed AI features aim to tailor the learning experience to each student’s needs, offering real-time support and potentially improving learning outcomes for slow learners.

title: SSGR-AR: Semantic-Enhanced Scene Graph Reasoning for Robust Video Action Recognition
authors: Daxu Shi, Fan Qi, Changsheng Xu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Knowledge Graph (ICKG)
abstract: Due to the inherent complexity of video data, video action recognition faces significant challenges in modeling spatial-temporal dynamics and handling diverse scene contexts. Although scene graph-based methods can effectively model interactions between entities, most existing approaches overlook the rich semantic information embedded within scene graphs. Additionally, integrating large language models (LLMs) for semantic enhancement often suffers from hallucination problems, potentially introducing incorrect reasoning that misleads action recognition. To address these limitations, we propose SSGR-AR, a novel framework that structurally represents videos through scene graphs and constrain LLM reasoning using structured semantic paths derived from scene graph knowledge, ensuring controllable and reliable semantic enrichment. Moreover, we formulate entity alignment as a link prediction task and leverage a graph transformer to model the dynamic evolution of actions, thereby enhancing the model's capacity for long-term temporal reasoning. Experimental results on three widely used benchmark datasets show that our method outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of action recognition accuracy and generalization robustness.

title: An LFCP-Based Line Protection for Full DC Offshore Wind Power System
authors: Xiuyan Wei, Guibin Zou
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power System and Renewable Energy (PSRE)
abstract: The full DC collection and transmission architecture represents an optimal solution for integrated offshore wind power systems, primarily due to its absence of multi-level voltage conversion and grid-following control complexity. However, this topology introduces critical challenges under the pole-to-pole faults (PPF), where the capacitive energy discharge of DC/DC converters generates a rapidly rising fault current, reaching extremely high peak amplitudes within microseconds, thereby severely jeopardizing the system reliability. To solve the problem, a protection scheme based on the line-mode fault component power (LFCP) is presented for DC collection line. Theoretical analysis reveals that during internal or external faults, the polarity of LFCP is different. Subsequently, a fault detection criterion leveraging the LFCP is established, and an associated protection strategy is developed. At last, extensive simulations validate that the LFCP based protection has simple algorithm, fast protection speed, and is less affected by the noise.

title: ATDP-HGNN: An Attention-Enhanced Dual-Hypergraph Neural Network for Drug-Pathway Association Prediction
authors: Yang Liu, Jinxiong Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Computer Science, Electronic Information Engineering and Intelligent Control Technology (CEI)
abstract: Drug discovery is a complex and costly process that requires accurate identification of drug-pathway associations. Traditional approaches often rely on binary interactions or low-order relationships, which fail to capture the higher-order dependencies among drugs, genes, and biological pathways. To address this limitation, we propose an Attention-enhanced Dual-Pathway Hypergraph Neural Network (ATDP-HGNN) that integrates drug molecular features and pathway gene expression data within a unified dual-hypergraph framework. The model constructs independent hypergraphs for drugs and pathways to encode multi-level associations and employs a dynamic attention mechanism to adaptively fuse drug-pathway interactions. Experimental results on two heterogeneous datasets demonstrate that ATDP-HGNN outperforms four representative baselines (iPaD, FacPad, GraphDPA, and MIDTI), achieving higher AUC and PRAUC values with improved robustness and interpretability. Ablation studies further confirm that both the hypergraph structure and attention mechanism contribute significantly to performance enhancement. These findings indicate that ATDP-HGNN provides an effective and interpretable approach for predicting potential drug-pathway associations, facilitating drug repositioning and systems pharmacology research.

title: Solar Panels Defect Detection and Classification Based on ResNet50
authors: Abdelhak Mehadjbia, Fouad Slaoui-Hasnaoui, Ala Eddine Kaddour Amraoui
publish: 2025 International Conference on Applied Artificial Intelligence, Data Engineering and Sciences (ICAIDES)
abstract: This study aims to enhance defect detection in solar panels through the application of convolutional neural networks (CNNs). The approach focuses on leveraging CNN architectures to automatically detect and classify external defects in photovoltaic modules, including clean panels, snow coverage, electrical faults, and physical damage. Such defects, if not identified promptly, can significantly reduce system performance. The networks were trained and evaluated in MATLAB Simulink, and the experimental results demonstrate their strong ability to recognize and categorize external anomalies with high accuracy and speed, thereby supporting preventive maintenance and efficient energy management. In addition, we performed a comparison and obtained good results, with the ResNet50 model reaching an accuracy of 94.14%.

title: MBS-Net: A Mamba-based Network for Efficient Remote Sensing Building Segmentation
authors: Xianyi Wang, Libo Wang, Xiaoliang Meng
publish: 2025 International Conference on Signal Processing and Communication Technology (SPCT)
abstract: Accurate and efficient building extraction from remote sensing (RS) imagery is crucial. Existing deep learning models suffer from high computational complexity, limited cross-domain generalization, and insufficient boundary delineation. We propose the Mamba-based Building Segmentation Network (MBS-Net), a novel lightweight semantic segmentation model based on the State Space Model (SSM) architecture. MBS-Net features a highly efficient encoder-decoder structure. Our core innovations include a Spatial Selective SSM (SS-SSM) module with a 2D spatial gating mechanism for adaptive feature enhancement, a Boundary-Aware Decoder (BAD) utilizing Sobel operators for precise boundary refinement, and a Multi-Scale Feature Fusion (MSFF) module within Mamba blocks to capture buildings of varying sizes. Furthermore, a comprehensive Cross-Domain Adaptation (CDA) mechanism is integrated to ensure robust generalization across diverse RS domains. MBS-Net achieves a superior balance between efficiency and segmentation accuracy, making it ideal for resource-constrained applications.

title: Soft-Masked Mixture of Experts for Point-Cloud Denoising
authors: Jian Liu, Yanli Yang, Mingwu Ren
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Computer Science, Electronic Information Engineering and Intelligent Control Technology (CEI)
abstract: With LiDAR increasingly used in autonomous driving and robotics, robust point-cloud denoising is essential for accurate 3D understanding. Yet mainstream score- and flowbased frameworks still struggle to balance structure preservation and noise suppression on highly non-uniform or reflective surfaces. We propose a lightweight, generic residual-head plugin that strengthens common denoisers via (i) adaptive residual control and (ii) selective expert fusion: a soft residual mask attenuates uncertain updates, and a two-expert MoE with a scalar gate plus mild balance regularizer blends detail-preserving and smoothing behaviors. The head is backbone-agnostic by design, requiring only per-point features and a residual/score output. We instantiate it on PD-LTS and add a minimal cross-backbone check showing gains on PD-Flow and IterativePFN. On PUNet, test EMD improves from 0.038 to 0.006 under matched training. Ablations and multi-seed statistics indicate the mask stabilizes early training while the gate improves the bias-variance tradeoff, supporting the method's stability, interpretability, and plug-and-play generalization.

title: Dual-View Compressed Knowledge Distillation for Defect Detection and Evaluation
authors: Jiaqi Wang, Xiaoyao Li, Zhe Zhang, Can Ding, Gufeng Gong, Yang Xiao
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Computer Science, Electronic Information Engineering and Intelligent Control Technology (CEI)
abstract: The growing demand for intelligent quality inspection and evaluation in industrial automation necessitates accurate and efficient defect detection. Supervised deep learning methods rely heavily on large labeled datasets, which are scarce in real-world settings, while existing unsupervised approaches struggle to balance detection performance and computational efficiency. To address this, we propose a lightweight defect detection and evaluation framework based on dual-view compressed knowledge distillation. Our method introduces a Dual-view Compression Module (DCM) to suppress anomalous features and amplify teacher-student representation discrepancies, alongside a structurally optimized lightweight student decoder. A hierarchical scoring mechanism combines multi-scale feature differences for robust defect localization. Extensive experiments on MVTec AD and BTAD benchmarks demonstrate our method's competitive performance and efficiency.

title: Graph Reinforcement Learning—Based Distribution Network Expansion Planning Algorithm
authors: Shangke Liu, Bin Bai, Bin Zhang, Rui Zhao, Yuanyuan Liu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Computer Science, Electronic Information Engineering and Intelligent Control Technology (CEI)
abstract: With the increasing penetration of distributed energy resources and new types of equipment, traditional distribution network planning methods cannot effectively cope with device heterogeneity, information complexity, and massive data. Therefore, this paper proposes a planning method for distribution line expansion based on graph reinforcement learning (GRL). First, a Markov decision process tailored to distribution expansion planning is formulated, in which the action space is compressed and the sensitivity to decision ordering is mitigated. Then, a line expansion model is established by designing the multiple constraints and the graph proximal policy optimization is employed to address the expansion planning problem of conventional line and tie line. The IEEE 69 bus expansion case demonstrates the feasibility of the proposed approach.

title: A High-Speed Desaturation Protection Strategy for IGBTs Based on Coordinated Parameter Design
authors: Chao You, Zhan He, Xiangxi Mu, Xueting Lei, Xin Chen
publish: 2025 2nd international conference on DC technologies and systems (DCTS)
abstract: The operational integrity of Insulated Gate Bipolar Transistors (IGBTs) within high-power conversion systems is significantly jeopardized by short-circuit (SC) events. Standard desaturation-based protection schemes frequently struggle to balance rapid response times with robust noise immunity, which often leads to delayed fault clearance and potential hardware destruction. To address this, this research introduces a multi-parameter coordinated optimization strategy specifically for accelerating desaturation identification. By constructing a precise dynamic analytical model, we establish the explicit functional relationship between key circuit variables and the detection dead zone. Furthermore, a specialized threshold calibration rule, grounded in the thermal-dependent saturation physics of the device, is implemented to minimize propagation delay while maintaining high false-trigger resistance. Validated on a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1700 ~\mathrm{V} / 300 ~\mathrm{A}$</tex> IGBT module, the proposed methodology achieves a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.5 \mu$</tex> s reduction in fault response latency during Fault Under Load (FUL) scenarios compared to baseline designs. This improvement effectively curtails short-circuit energy dissipation, thereby preventing electrode degradation and bolstering overall system resilience.

title: Factor Graph Optimization based Sensor Fusion Positioning Algorithm for UAV in GPS-denied Environment
authors: Chuncheng Wang, Abiirbek Kuanysh, Xinying Zhao, Huijian Liang, Beiya Yang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Human-Computer Interaction and Robotics (AIHCIR)
abstract: In GPS-denied environments, especially in the dark and confined environments, traditional positioning methods are prone to performance degradation. Ultra-wideband (UWB) technology, which utilizes extremely wide bandwidth to achieve high-precision positioning, has attracted extensive attention under such circumstances. However, it also faces challenges such as measurement noise and accuracy degradation under non-line-of-sight (NLOS) conditions. To address the aforementioned issues, in this article, a fusion positioning method based on Factor Graph Optimization (FGO) that integrates IMU and UWB through data fusion is proposed. This approach ultimately achieves high-precision positioning for UAVs in their operational environments. According to the simulation results, by adopting the factor graph optimization, the proposed sensor fusion algorithm can achieve the median positioning error, the 95th positioning error, the root mean square error (RMSE), and the average standard deviation for RMSE with 0.0356 m, 0.0733 m, 0.0433 m, and 0.0197 m in the focused environments.

title: SplitFusion: Asymmetric Parallel Inference for Diffusion Model in Heterogeneous Computility Network
authors: KaiFang Li, Renchao Xie, Qinqin Tang, Ziyue You
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Human-Computer Interaction and Robotics (AIHCIR)
abstract: Parallel acceleration of diffusion model inference for high-resolution image generation across multiple GPUs has achieved remarkable success. The common approach partitions the image into uniform patches for distributed parallel computing. However, in the GPU inference cluster, it is difficult to maintain consistent computing capabilities across GPU nodes during inference. Assigning equal tasks can readily cause the Straggler Problem. To tackle this problem, we propose SplitFusion, a innovative framework incorporating two key components: Displaced Asymmetric Patch Parallelism and Resource-Aware Asymmetric Patch Partitioning. Displaced Asymmetric Patch Parallelism enables cross-patch semantic exchange through sliding observation windows and a fixed-size buffer, circumventing NCCL's uniform data size constraints. Resource-Aware Asymmetric Patch Partitioning predicts the computational capabilities of devices through short-term resource monitoring to guide the allocation of computational tasks. Extensive experiments demonstrate that in scenarios with unequal idle resources across computational devices, our approach achieves more efficient utilization of computational resources compared to equal distribution strategies.

title: Analysis of the Impact of the LVRT Threshold on the Active Power Transfer Capability of Renewable Energy
authors: Zhenjun Gao, Ping Wei, Xuetao Dong, Chao Huo
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power System and Renewable Energy (PSRE)
abstract: Conventional low voltage ride-through strategies, which prioritize reactive current injection for voltage support, often lead to a significant curtailment of active power, thereby jeopardizing system frequency stability. This paper analyzes the impact of the Low voltage ride-through (LVRT) threshold on active power output capability from three perspectives: the grid's resistance-to-reactance (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{R} / \mathrm{X}$</tex>) ratio, grid strength, and the probability distribution of voltage fault depth. The analysis reveals that for grids with a high R/X ratio, lowering the LVRT threshold yields a greater increase in active power output compared to grids with a low R/X ratio. In strong grids, lowering the LVRT threshold enhances active power output. For weak grids, lowering the LVRT threshold reduces active power capability during shallow faults but increases it during deep faults. Finally, simulation results verify the correctness of the analysis presented in this paper.

title: Smart Movement: Identifying Factors Impact on Purchase Intention of E-Motorcycle in Vietnam
authors: Tuan-Kiet H.V. Truong, Thang Hong Vo
publish: 2025 International Conference on Applied Artificial Intelligence, Data Engineering and Sciences (ICAIDES)
abstract: The main objective of this study is to identify the factors affecting the intention to purchase electric motorbikes in Vietnam. The research subjects are customers who purchase motorbikes at stores. The sampling method used to collect data using non-probability convenience techniques. Data collection was done using an online survey tool called Google Form, which was linked by QR codes. The survey collected a total of 200 responses. This study used structural equation modeling (SEM). The study demonstrated the factors affecting the intention to purchase electric motorbikes: attitude, technology and subjective norms. In addition, the study demonstrated that environmental awareness has an impact on subjective norms and attitudes. At the same time, environmental awareness indirectly affects purchase intention through attitudes and subjective norms. Finally, the study did not find any impact of purchase cost on customers’ intention to purchase electric motorbikes. This study contributes to the literature for stakeholders to develop and propose appropriate policies to encourage consumers to switch from traditional motorbikes to electric vehicles in Vietnam’s green transportation.

title: Fault Location of a Distribution Network Hierarchical Model with a Distribution Generator Based on Improved Dung Beetle Optimization Algorithm
authors: Penghuan Ma, Yaojia Huo, Zecheng Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power System and Renewable Energy (PSRE)
abstract: Aiming at the problems of low accuracy and slow convergence speed of the traditional intelligent optimization problem in fault localization of distribution networks containing distributed power sources, a hierarchical fault localization method based on the improved dung beetle optimization algorithm is proposed. Firstly, An initial population with uniform distribution is generated using Tent chaotic mapping. After that, a combined mutation scheme and the sine-cosine algorithm are incorporated to boost local search efficiency and speed up convergence. Secondly, the distribution network model is simplified to locate the fault region using the improved dung beetle optimization algorithm, and the fault region is located twice using the exhaustive method. The feasibility of the proposed algorithm is verified by experimentally analyzing single-point faults and multi-point faults.

title: V-Model Design and Experimental Validation for Robust Direct Power Control of Wind Energy Conversion Systems
authors: Yassine Seghrouchni, Mourad Yessef, Saad Motahhir, Badre Bossoufi, Saad A. Alqahtani, Z.M.S. El-Barbary
abstract: The V-model is a structured engineering framework used in the automotive and aeronautical industries. Each development phase, in this model, corresponds to a specific validation step. This study presents the first of its kind application of the V-model to the wind energy industry, covering the design, implementation, and validation of a direct power control algorithm with proportional-integral (DPC-PI) for a doubly fed induction generator (DFIG). The validation process proceeds through three rigorous stages: Model-in-the-Loop (MIL), Software-in-the-Loop (SIL), and Processor-in-the-Loop (PIL). Under a wind speed step from 6 m/s to 10 m/s, results show that DPC-PI reduces steady-state error by 83.7%, overshoot by 39.4%, and total harmonic distortion (THD) by 92% compared to classical DPC. Next to prove the adaptability of our control to the variations of the environment a conducted parameter variation test demonstrated stable operation and ripple suppression for both active and reactive power. Finally, an assessed operating mode test in sub-synchronous, synchronous, and super-synchronous regions show a reduction of up to 86.4% in power ripples and a THD below 0.9%. Under variable wind conditions, the controller holds THD at 0.84%, outperforming some of the recent methods. In the final phase, the PIL test was executed on the STM32F429 to reveal the real-time performance of this control.

title: Gait Planning & Adaptive Impedance Control for Turning Walk Based on a Self-Balancing Lower Limb Exoskeleton
authors: Xihao Wang, Shisheng Zhang, Jinke Li, Weijie Sun, Zengle Ren, Wujing Cao, Meng Yin, Xinyu Wu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: Self-balancing lower limb exoskeletons (SBLLE) hold the promise of helping individuals with diverse mobility impairments regain their ability to walk. Equipping exoskeletons with stable turning capabilities is crucial for their real-world application. This paper presents an effective control framework that enables stable turning motions in SBLLE without relying on external assistive devices. A turn-specific gait planner has been designed to generate stable reference gaits. Moreover, an adaptive variable impedance controller (AVIC) is introduced, which adjusts the center of mass (CoM) motion in real time to maintain balance during walking, even when carrying different patients. The proposed approach is validated through simulations, comparative studies, and multi-stage human-subject experiments with ten participants, ranging from healthy users to individuals with severe lower-limb motor impairment. Results consistently demonstrate stable turning performance, with the Zero Moment Point (ZMP) remaining within the support polygon during the entire walking process.

title: SAM-PTx: Text-Guided Fine-Tuning of SAM with Parameter-Efficient, Parallel-Text Adapters
authors: Shayan Jalilian, Abdul Bais
abstract: The Segment Anything Model (SAM) has demonstrated impressive generalization in prompt-based segmentation. Yet, the potential of semantic text prompts remains underexplored compared to traditional spatial prompts, such as points and boxes. This paper introduces SAM-PTx, a parameter-efficient approach for adapting SAM using frozen CLIP-derived text embeddings as class-level semantic guidance. Specifically, we propose a lightweight adapter, the Parallel-Text Adapter, that injects text embeddings into SAM’s image encoder, enabling semantics-guided segmentation while keeping most of the original architecture frozen. Through supervised experiments and ablations on the low-data subsets of COCO and ADE20K as well as the COD10K dataset, we show that incorporating fixed text embeddings as additional inputs improves segmentation performance over purely spatial prompt baselines. To our knowledge, this is the first work to use text prompts for segmentation on the COD10K dataset. These results suggest that integrating semantic conditioning into SAM’s architecture offers a practical, scalable path to efficient adaptation with minimal computational complexity.

title: Neural Learning Control of Fighter Aircraft at High-Angle-of-Attack Maneuvers with Online Recorded Data and Disturbance Observer
authors: Jiashang Yu, Jiaju Yu

title: Deep reinforcement learning for chaos control of a nonlinear jumping quarter-car model
authors: Masahisa Watanabe
abstract: Vibrations can reduce the controllability of vehicles and can be uncomfortable for passengers. In particular, nonlinear vibrations can lead to larger amplitudes and complex behaviors. Among these vibrations, chaotic vibrations are inherently unpredictable and may lead to instability, which is highly undesirable in practical applications. Although several control methods have been developed to eliminate chaotic vibrations in active suspension systems, they require a priori knowledge about vehicle systems. Thus, designing chaos controllers for practical scenarios can be very challenging. In this study, we propose a method based on machine learning to overcome this limitation. The deep deterministic policy gradient algorithm is used to learn optimal control input to suppress chaotic vibrations. As a typical model of nonlinear motion, we considered a quarter-car model with jumping nonlinearity and trained a reinforcement learning model to suppress chaotic vibrations. The numerical results show that learned policies were able to suppress chaotic vibration and reduce the overall level of vibration. The obtained policies were evaluated across a wide range of forcing frequencies and simulations with stochastic excitation noises. The results demonstrate that chaos control based on deep reinforcement learning was able to reduce vibrations and stabilize chaotic behavior effectively in this application.
